document.masterDocTitle: A synopsis of the Neotropical genus Protoneura (Odonata: Coenagrionidae)

Diagnosis. Male cercus morphology, with a medial sclerotized branch which ends on a tooth directed medioventrally and remainder of cercus foliaceous, medially concave, with a small triangular tooth on outer ventrobasal edge, and a long, curved thick pointed tooth at medial ventrobasal edge directed medially ( Figs. 113 ), is shared with
P. caligata
,
P. capillaris
,
P. dunklei
and
P. viridis
( Figs. 100 ; 102; 106; 117). Within this group, P.

sanguinipes
resembles
P. dunklei
by the medial sclerotized branch of male cercus ending on a broad triangular tip located at about midlength of cercus ( Figs. 106 ; 113) and by distal margin of genital ligula triangularly convex with laterodistal corners not projected ventrally ( Figs. 80 ; 87); in
P. caligata
,
P. capillaris
, and
P. viridis
the medial branch ends on a tooth directed medioventrally located at cercus tip ( Figs. 100 ; 102; 106; 117), and distal margin of genital ligula is straight with laterodistal corners projected ventrally ( Figs. 74 ; 76; 93).
Protoneura sanguinipes
differs from males of all four species by the entirely reddish orange femora, tibiae and tarsi ( Fig. 17 ), which have various extents of dark colors in the other species ( Figs. 4 ; 6; 21). Female can be distinguished from all congeners except
P. dunklei
by its trilobed posterior lobe of pronotum directed dorsally and with medial lobe entire and smoothly convex (Fig. 63a) and by the oval mesostigmal plate (Fig. 63b). It differs from
P. dunklei
by flexor surface of tibiae pale ( Fig. 41 ; dark in
P. dunklei
, Fig. 34 ).

Habitat and biology. Females oviposit on sedges near banks while still in tandem with males ( Westfall 1987 ). Distribution. Dominican Republic ( Fig. 119 ). Assessed as Endangered by IUCN ( Paulson 2009f ).
